a.g: Alif, Lam, Meem.
This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah -
Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them,
And who believe in what has been revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you, and of the Hereafter they are certain [in faith].
Those are upon [right] guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful.
Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe.

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
Indeed, the second heart [qalb] is the forsaken heart, filled with caprice [hawa], stained with blameworthy traits and foul impurities, opened within it are the gates of the devils, and sealed from it are the gates of the angels. The origin of evil within it is that a thought [khÄtir] from caprice [hawa] sparks within it and whispers, so the heart [qalb] looks to the ruler, the intellect [â€˜aql], to seek its verdict and uncover the face of what is correct in it. But the intellect [â€˜aql] has grown accustomed to serving caprice [hawa] and has become intimate with it, persisting in devising stratagems for it and in aiding the caprice [hawa]. Thus, the lower self [nafs] takes control and assists it, so the breast [á¹£adr] expands with caprice [hawa] and its darknesses spread within it due to the withholding of the intellect's [â€˜aql] army from repelling it. The authority of Satan [shayá¹­Än] strengthens due to the expanse of its place because of the spread of caprice [hawa], so it approaches with adornment, delusion, and false hopes, and inspires that as an embellishment of speech, a delusion. Thus, the authority of faith [Ä«mÄn] in the promise and the threat weakens, and the light [nÅ«r] of certainty [yaqÄ«n] from the fear of the Hereafter dims, for from the caprice [hawa] ascends a dark smoke to the heart [qalb] which fills its corners until its lights [anwÄr] are extinguished. The intellect [â€˜aql] becomes like an eye whose lids are filled with smoke, so it is unable to see. Thus does the dominance of desire [shahwa] act upon the heart [qalb] until there remains no possibility for the heart [qalb] to pause and gain insight [istibá¹£Är], even if an admonisher gave it sight and made it hear what is the truth in it, it would be blind to understanding and deaf to hearing. Desire [shahwa] rages within it, Satan [shayá¹­Än] prevails, and the limbs move in accordance with caprice [hawa], so disobedience [maâ€˜á¹£iya] appears into the visible world [â€˜Älam al-shahÄda] from the unseen world [â€˜Älam al-ghayb] by the decree [qaá¸Äâ€™] and predestination [qadar] of God, Exalted is He. To such a heart [qalb] is the allusion in His saying, Exalted is He: "Have you seen he who has taken his caprice [hawa] as his god? Then would you be a guardian over him?" [25:43] and "Or do you suppose that most of them hear or understand? They are but like cattle. Nay, they are further astray from the way." [25:44] and in His saying, Mighty and Majestic: "The Word has been justified against most of them, for they do not believe." [36:7] and in His saying: "Alike it is to them whether you warn them or warn them not; they do not believe." [2:6]

a.g: Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and upon their hearing, and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment.
And of the people are some who say, "We believe in Allah and the Last Day," but they are not believers.
They [think to] deceive Allah and those who believe, but they deceive not except themselves and perceive [it] not.
In their hearts is disease, so Allah has increased their disease; and for them is a painful punishment because they [habitually] used to lie.
And when it is said to them, "Do not cause corruption on the earth," they say, "We are but reformers."
Unquestionably, it is they who are the corrupters, but they perceive [it] not.
And when it is said to them, "Believe as the people have believed," they say, "Should we believe as the foolish have believed?" Unquestionably, it is they who are the foolish, but they know [it] not.
And when they meet those who believe, they say, "We believe"; but when they are alone with their evil ones, they say, "Indeed, we are with you; we were only mockers."
[But] Allah mocks them and prolongs them in their transgression [while] they wander blindly.
Those are the ones who have purchased error [in exchange] for guidance, so their transaction has brought no profit, nor were they guided.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Poverty and Abstinence
Indeed, as for the hypocrites [munafiqun], they fled from the battle [zahf] out of fear of death, so it was said to them: "Indeed, the death you flee from, it will surely meet you." Their preference for survival over martyrdom [shahada] is an exchange of that which is lower [adna] for that which is better [khayr]. Those are the ones who purchased misguidance [dalala] with guidance [huda], so their transaction [tijara] gained no profit, and they were not guided [muhtadin]. And as for the sincere ones [mukhlisun], then Allah, the Exalted, has purchased from them their souls [anfus] and their wealth [amwal] in exchange for Paradise [Jannah] for them. When they saw that they had left behind, for example, the enjoyment of twenty or thirty years, for the enjoyment of eternity [abad], they rejoiced at the sale [bay'] they had transacted. This is the clarification of that which is disdained.

a.g: Their example is that of one who kindled a fire, but when it illuminated what was around him, Allah took away their light and left them in darkness [so] they could not see.
Deaf, dumb and blind - so they will not return [to the right path].

Or [it is] like a rainstorm from the sky within which is darkness, thunder and lightning. They put their fingers in their ears against the thunderclaps in dread of death. But Allah is encompassing of the disbelievers.

The lightning almost snatches away their sight. Every time it lights [the way] for them, they walk therein; but when darkness comes over them, they stand [still]. And if Allah had willed, He could have taken away their hearing and their sight. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.
O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous -

[He] who made for you the earth a bed [spread out] and the sky a ceiling and sent down from the sky, rain and brought forth thereby fruits as provision for you. So do not attribute to Allah equals while you know [that there is nothing similar to Him].
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 4: Meditation
Indeed, if you have come to know the way of reflection [fikr] within your own self, then reflect upon the earth [ard], which is your dwelling place, then upon its rivers, its mountains, and its minerals. Then ascend from it to the dominion [malakut] of the heavens. As for the earth, from His signs [ayat] is that He created the earth as a carpet [firash] and a resting place [mihad], and He made in it wide roads, and He made it subservient [dhulul] so that you may walk upon its shoulders, and He made it stable, not moving, and He set firm within it mountains as pegs for it, preventing it from swaying. Then He expanded its regions until human beings were incapable of reaching all its sides, even if their lifespans were long and their travels frequent. So the Most High said: "And the heavenâ€”We constructed it with strength, and indeed, We are its expander. And the earthâ€”We spread it out, and how excellent are We as spreaders!" And He, the Most High, said: "It is He who made the earth subservient [dhulul] for you, so walk upon its shoulders." And He, the Most High, said: "He who made the earth a carpet [firash] for you." And He has frequently mentioned the earth [ard] in His Mighty Book so that one may reflect upon its wonders. Its surface is a dwelling for the living, and its interior is a resting place for the dead. He, the Most High, said: "Have We not made the earth a container [kifat], of the living and the dead?" So look at the earth when it is dead; then when He sends down water upon it, it quivers, swells, becomes green, and brings forth wondrous vegetation, and from it emerge various kinds of animals. Then look how He has made firm the sides of the earth with the towering, lofty, solid, hard mountains, and how He has deposited waters beneath it, so He causes springs to gush forth and makes rivers flow upon its face, and He brings forth from dry stones and from dark soil a delicate, sweet, pure, cool water, and He made with it every living thing. So He brings forth with it varieties of trees and vegetation: from grain, and grapes, and herbs, and olives, and date palms, and pomegranates, and many fruits that cannot be counted, differing in shapes, colors, tastes, attributes, and scents, some excelling over others in food, watered by one water and emerging from one earth. If you say, "Their difference is due to the difference in their seeds and origins," then when was there in the seed a date palm wrapped with clusters of fresh dates? And when was there in a single grain a hundred ears, in every ear a hundred? Then look at the land of the deserts and search its surface and its interior, and you will see it as similar soil. Then when He sends down water upon it, it quivers, swells, and brings forth from every delightful pair different colors and vegetation, similar and dissimilar, each one with a taste, a scent, a color, and a shape differing from the other. So look at their multitude, the difference in their kinds, the abundance of their forms, then the difference in the natures of the plants and the abundance of their benefits, and how Allah, the Most High, has deposited in the plants strange benefits: this plant nourishes, and this strengthens, and this enlivens, and this kills, and this cools, and this heats, and this, when it reaches the stomach, suppresses yellow bile from the depths of the veins, and this transforms into yellow bile, and this suppresses phlegm and black bile, and this transforms into them, and this purifies the blood, and this dissolves blood, and this gladdens, and this induces sleep, and this strengthens, and this weakens. Not a single leaf or blade of grass sprouts from the earth except that within it are benefits which humankind cannot fully comprehend. And each one of these plants requires the farmer, in its cultivation, a specific action: the date palm benefits from generosity, the vine is pruned, the crop is cleared of weeds and thickets. And some of it is cultivated by scattering the seed in the earth, and some by planting cuttings, and some is grafted onto trees.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
Indeed, to this secret [sirr] points what has been narrated: that one of the Prophets passed by a small stone from which much water was flowing, and he was astonished by it. So Allah, the Exalted, made it speak, and it said: "Ever since I heard His statement, the Exalted: 'Its fuel is people and stones [hijarah],' I have been weeping from fear of it." So he asked it to grant him refuge from the Fire, and it granted him refuge. Then he saw it after a period in a similar state, and said: "Why do you weep now?" It said: "That was the weeping of fear [khawf], and this is the weeping of gratitude [shukr] and joy [surur]." And the heart [qalb] of the servant is like the stone, or harder in hardness [qaswah]; and its hardness does not depart except through weeping in the state of fear and gratitude together.

a.g: Indeed, Allah is not timid to present an example - that of a mosquito or what is smaller than it. And those who have believed know that it is the truth from their Lord. But as for those who disbelieve, they say, "What did Allah intend by this as an example?" He misleads many thereby and guides many thereby. And He misleads not except the defiantly disobedient,
Who break the covenant of Allah after contracting it and sever that which Allah has ordered to be joined and cause corruption on earth. It is those who are the losers.
How can you disbelieve in Allah when you were lifeless and He brought you to life; then He will cause you to die, then He will bring you [back] to life, and then to Him you will be returned.
It is He who created for you all of that which is on the earth. Then He directed Himself to the heaven, [His being above all creation], and made them seven heavens, and He is Knowing of all things.

a.g: And [mention, O Muhammad], when your Lord said to the angels, "Indeed, I will make upon the earth a successive authority." They said, "Will You place upon it one who causes corruption therein and sheds blood, while we declare Your praise and sanctify You?" Allah said, "Indeed, I know that which you do not know."
And He taught Adam the names - all of them. Then He showed them to the angels and said, "Inform Me of the names of these, if you are truthful."
They said, "Exalted are You; we have no knowledge except what You have taught us. Indeed, it is You who is the Knowing, the Wise."

He said, "O Adam, inform them of their names." And when he had informed them of their names, He said, "Did I not tell you that I know the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and the earth? And I know what you reveal and what you have concealed."
And [mention] when We said to the angels, "Prostrate before Adam"; so they prostrated, except for Iblees. He refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers.

a.g: O Children of Israel, remember My favor that I have bestowed upon you and that I preferred you over the worlds.
And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all, nor will intercession be accepted from it, nor will compensation be taken from it, nor will they be aided.

And [recall] when We saved your forefathers from the people of Pharaoh, who afflicted you with the worst torment, slaughtering your [newborn] sons and keeping your females alive. And in that was a great trial from your Lord.
And [recall] when We parted the sea for you and saved you and drowned the people of Pharaoh while you were looking on.
And [recall] when We made an appointment with Moses for forty nights. Then you took [for worship] the calf after him, while you were wrongdoers.
Then We forgave you after that so perhaps you would be grateful.
And [recall] when We gave Moses the Scripture and criterion that perhaps you would be guided.

And [recall] when Moses said to his people, "O my people, indeed you have wronged yourselves by your taking of the calf [for worship]. So repent to your Creator and kill yourselves. That is best for [all of] you in the sight of your Creator." Then He accepted your repentance; indeed, He is the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful.
And [recall] when you said, "O Moses, we will never believe you until we see Allah outright"; so the thunderbolt took you while you were looking on.
Then We revived you after your death that perhaps you would be grateful.

And We shaded you with clouds and sent down to you manna and quails, [saying], "Eat from the good things with which We have provided you." And they wronged Us not - but they were [only] wronging themselves.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Eating
Indeed, and He, the Exalted, said in describing the good things [al-tayyibat]: "And We sent down upon you the manna [al-mann] and the quails [al-salwa]." The manna [al-mann] is honey, and the quails [al-salwa] is meat. It is called *salwa* because one finds solace [yata-salla] in it from all other condiments, and nothing else takes its place. And for that reason, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The master of condiments is meat." Then He said, after mentioning the manna [al-mann] and the quails [al-salwa]: "Eat from the good things [al-tayyibat] We have provided for you." Thus, meat and sweetness are from the good things [al-tayyibat].

a.g: And [recall] when We said, "Enter this city and eat from it wherever you will in [ease and] abundance, and enter the gate bowing humbly and say, 'Relieve us of our burdens.' We will [then] forgive your sins for you, and We will increase the doers of good [in goodness and reward]."

But those who wronged changed [those words] to a statement other than that which had been said to them, so We sent down upon those who wronged a punishment from the sky because they were defiantly disobeying.

And [recall] when Moses prayed for water for his people, so We said, "Strike with your staff the stone." And there gushed forth from it twelve springs, and every people knew its watering place. "Eat and drink from the provision of Allah, and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption."

And [recall] when you said, "O Moses, we can never endure one [kind of] food. So call upon your Lord to bring forth for us from the earth its green herbs and its cucumbers and its garlic and its lentils and its onions." [Moses] said, "Would you exchange what is better for what is less? Go into [any] settlement and indeed, you will have what you have asked." And they were covered with humiliation and poverty and returned with anger from Allah [upon them]. That was because they [repeatedly] disbelieved in the signs of Allah and killed the prophets without right. That was because they disobeyed and were [habitually] transgressing.

Indeed, those who believed and those who were Jews or Christians or Sabeans [before Prophet Muhammad] - those [among them] who believed in Allah and the Last Day and did righteousness - will have their reward with their Lord, and no fear will there be concerning them, nor will they grieve.

And [recall] when We took your covenant, [O Children of Israel, to abide by the Torah] and We raised over you the mount, [saying], "Take what We have given you with determination and remember what is in it that perhaps you may become righteous."
Then you turned away after that. And if not for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy, you would have been among the losers.
And you had already known about those who transgressed among you concerning the sabbath, and We said to them, "Be apes, despised."
And We made it a deterrent punishment for those who were present and those who succeeded [them] and a lesson for those who fear Allah.
And [recall] when Moses said to his people, "Indeed, Allah commands you to slaughter a cow." They said, "Do you take us in ridicule?" He said, "I seek refuge in Allah from being among the ignorant."
They said, "Call upon your Lord to make clear to us what it is." [Moses] said, "[Allah] says, 'It is a cow which is neither old nor virgin, but median between that,' so do what you are commanded."
They said, "Call upon your Lord to show us what is her color." He said, "He says, 'It is a yellow cow, bright in color - pleasing to the observers.' "
They said, "Call upon your Lord to make clear to us what it is. Indeed, [all] cows look alike to us. And indeed we, if Allah wills, will be guided."

He said, "He says, 'It is a cow neither trained to plow the earth nor to irrigate the field, one free from fault with no spot upon her.' " They said, "Now you have come with the truth." So they slaughtered her, but they could hardly do it.
And [recall] when you slew a man and disputed over it, but Allah was to bring out that which you were concealing.
So, We said, "Strike the slain man with part of it." Thus does Allah bring the dead to life, and He shows you His signs that you might reason.

Then your hearts became hardened after that, being like stones or even harder. For indeed, there are stones from which rivers burst forth, and there are some of them that split open and water comes out, and there are some of them that fall down for fear of Allah. And Allah is not unaware of what you do.

a.g: So woe to those who write the "scripture" with their own hands, then say, "This is from Allah," in order to exchange it for a small price. Woe to them for what their hands have written and woe to them for what they earn.

And they say, "Never will the Fire touch us, except for a few days." Say, "Have you taken a covenant with Allah? For Allah will never break His covenant. Or do you say about Allah that which you do not know?"

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Zakat
Indeed, the least of what one forfeits in disputation [mujadala], contention [mira'], and argumentation [jidal] is the sweetness of speech [tayyib al-kalam] and the reward promised for it; for the lowest degree of sweet speech is its outward display, and there is no coarseness in speech greater than accusation and objection, the essence of which is either to declare ignorance [tajhil] or to declare falsehood [takdhib]. For whoever argues [jadal] with another, contends [mara] with him, or disputes [khasama] him has, in effect, declared him ignorant or declared him a liar, thereby forfeiting the sweetness of speech. And Ibn 'Abbas also said: "If Pharaoh were to say something good to me, I would return it to him."

a.g: And [recall] when We took your covenant, [saying], "Do not shed each other's blood or evict one another from your homes." Then you acknowledged [this] while you were witnessing.

Then, you are those [same ones who are] killing one another and evicting a party of your people from their homes, cooperating against them in sin and aggression. And if they come to you as captives, you ransom them, although their eviction was forbidden to you. So do you believe in part of the Scripture and disbelieve in part? Then what is the recompense for those who do that among you except disgrace in worldly life; and on the Day of Resurrection they will be sent back to the severest of punishment. And Allah is not unaware of what you do.
Those are the ones who have bought the life of this world [in exchange] for the Hereafter, so the punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be aided.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
Indeed, the first example is the delusion [ghurur] of the disbelievers. Among them are those deluded by the worldly life [al-hayat al-dunya], and among them are those deluded by delusion concerning Allah. As for those deluded by the worldly life: they are those who said: 'Cash [al-naqd] is better than credit [al-nasi'ah], and the world [al-dunya] is cash and the Hereafter [al-akhirah] is credit; it is therefore better, so it is necessary to prefer it.' And they said: 'Certainty [al-yaqin] is better than doubt, and the pleasures of the world are certainty and the pleasures of the Hereafter are doubt, so do not abandon certainty for doubt.' And these are corrupt syllogisms resembling the syllogism of Iblis when he said, 'I am better than him; You created me from fire and created him from clay.' And to these is the allusion in His saying, the Most High: "Those are the ones who have purchased the worldly life [al-hayat al-dunya] for the Hereafter [al-akhirah], so the punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be aided." And the cure for this delusion [ghurur] is either by affirming faith [tasdiq al-iman] or by proof [al-burhan]. As for affirmation by mere faith [tasdiq bi-mujarrad al-iman], it is to affirm Allah, the Most High, in His saying: "What is with you will be exhausted, and what is with Allah is enduring," and in His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: "And what is with Allah is better," and His saying: "And the Hereafter [al-akhirah] is better and more enduring," and His saying: "And the worldly life [al-hayat al-dunya] is not but the enjoyment of delusion [mata' al-ghurur]," and His saying: "So let not the worldly life [al-hayat al-dunya] delude you." And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, informed groups of the disbelievers of this, so they followed him and affirmed him and believed in him, and they did not demand proof from him. And among them were those who said: 'I adjure you by Allah, did Allah send you as a messenger?' He would say, 'Yes,' and they would affirm. And this is the faith [iman] of the common people, and it delivers from delusion [ghurur]. And this is like the station of a child affirming his father that attending school is better than attending the playground, even though he does not know the aspect of its being better. As for knowledge [al-ma'rifah] by clarification and proof [al-bayan wa al-burhan], it is to know the aspect of corruption in this syllogism which Satan has composed in his heart [qalb]. For every deluded one has a cause for his delusion [ghurur], and that cause is evidence, and every evidence is a type of syllogism that occurs in the soul [nafs] and begets tranquility towards it, even if its possessor is not aware of it and cannot compose it in the words of the scholars. So the syllogism which Satan composed has two principles. The first is that the world [al-dunya] is cash [al-naqd] and the Hereafter [al-akhirah] is credit [al-nasi'ah], and this is correct. The other is his saying that cash is better than credit, and this is the place of deception. The matter is not so. Rather, if the cash is equal to the credit in amount and objective, then it is better. But if it is less than it, then the credit is better. For the deluded disbeliever spends in his trade a dirham to receive ten on credit, and he does not say, 'Cash is better than credit, so I will not leave it.' And when the doctor warns him against fruits and delights of foods, he leaves that immediately, fearing the pain of illness in the future; he has thus left the cash and been content with the credit. And all merchants sail the seas and toil in travels for cash, for the sake of comfort and profit on credit. So if ten in the second instance is better than one in the present instance, then relate the pleasure of the world [al-dunya] in terms of its duration to the duration of the Hereafter [al-akhirah]. For the utmost lifespan of a human is one hundred years, and it is not a tenth of a tenth of a part of a thousand thousand parts of the Hereafter. So it is as if he left one to receive a thousand thousand, nay, to receive what has no end and no limit.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
Indeed, Allah, glorified and sublime, has stipulated for its true reality [haqiqah] the truthfulness [sidq] in love [hubb] to be killing in the way of Allah [fi sabil Allah], when they said, "Indeed, we love Allah," so He made killing in the way of Allah and seeking martyrdom [shahadah] its sign, and He, the Exalted, said: "Indeed, Allah loves those who fight in His cause in ranks..." and He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "...they fight in the way of Allah, so they kill and are killed." And He recited His saying, the Exalted: "...then wish for death, if you should be truthful." If you say: "He who does not love death, can it be conceived that he is a lover of Allah?" Then I say: The aversion to death [karahiyat al-mawt] may be due to love for the world [dunya] and sorrow over separation from family, wealth, and children, and this contradicts the perfection of love for Allah, the Exalted, for the perfect love [al-hubb al-kamil] is that which consumes the entire heart [qalb]. However, it is not far-fetched that along with love for family and children, there may be a weak trace of love for Allah, the Exalted, for people are varied in their love. As for the second cause for aversion: it is that the servant ['abd] is at the beginning of the station of love [maqam al-mahabbah] and does not dislike death itself, but rather dislikes its hastening before he has prepared to meet Allah. That does not indicate weakness of love. It is like the lover whose news reached him of the arrival of his beloved to him, so he wished for his arrival to be delayed an hour so he could prepare his house for him and arrange his means to meet him as he desires, with a heart empty of distractions and a back lightened of obstacles. So aversion for this reason does not contradict the perfection of love at all, and its sign is diligence in work and the total preoccupation of concern in preparation.

a.g: Say, "Whoever is an enemy to Gabriel - it is [none but] he who has brought the Qur'an down upon your heart, [O Muhammad], by permission of Allah, confirming that which was before it and as guidance and good tidings for the believers."
Whoever is an enemy to Allah and His angels and His messengers and Gabriel and Michael - then indeed, Allah is an enemy to the disbelievers.
And We have certainly revealed to you verses [which are] clear proofs, and no one would deny them except the defiantly disobedient.
Is it not [true] that every time they took a covenant a party of them threw it away? But, [in fact], most of them do not believe.

And when a messenger from Allah came to them confirming that which was with them, a party of those who had been given the Scripture threw the Scripture of Allah behind their backs as if they did not know [what it contained].

And they followed [instead] what the devils had recited during the reign of Solomon. It was not Solomon who disbelieved, but the devils disbelieved, teaching people magic and that which was revealed to the two angels at Babylon, Harut and Marut. But the two angels do not teach anyone unless they say, "We are a trial, so do not disbelieve [by practicing magic]." And [yet] they learn from them that by which they cause separation between a man and his wife. But they do not harm anyone through it except by permission of Allah. And the people learn what harms them and does not benefit them. But the Children of Israel certainly knew that whoever purchased the magic would not have in the Hereafter any share. And wretched is that for which they sold themselves, if they only knew.
And if they had believed and feared Allah, then the reward from Allah would have been [far] better, if they only knew.
O you who have believed, say not [to Allah 's Messenger], "Ra'ina" but say, "Unthurna" and listen. And for the disbelievers is a painful punishment.

Neither those who disbelieve from the People of the Scripture nor the polytheists wish that any good should be sent down to you from your Lord. But Allah selects for His mercy whom He wills, and Allah is the possessor of great bounty.
We do not abrogate a verse or cause it to be forgotten except that We bring forth [one] better than it or similar to it. Do you not know that Allah is over all things competent?
Do you not know that to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and [that] you have not besides Allah any protector or any helper?
Or do you intend to ask your Messenger as Moses was asked before? And whoever exchanges faith for disbelief has certainly strayed from the soundness of the way.

Many of the People of the Scripture wish they could turn you back to disbelief after you have believed, out of envy from themselves [even] after the truth has become clear to them. So pardon and overlook until Allah delivers His command. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
Indeed, many of the People of the Book [Ahl al-Kitab] wish they could turn you back to disbelief after your faith, out of envy [hasad] from their own selves." So, the Exalted informs that their love for the removal of the blessing of faith is envy [hasad]. Thus, the definition of envy [hasad] is to dislike the blessing [ni'mah] and to love its removal from the one upon whom it has been bestowed. As for the firstâ€”this is forbidden in every circumstance, except for a blessing [ni'mah] obtained by a wicked person or a disbeliever, and he uses it to stir up strife [fitnah], corrupt relations, and harm the truth [haqq]. Then, your dislike of it and your love for its removal does not harm you, for you do not love its removal inasmuch as it is a blessing [ni'mah], but rather inasmuch as it is an instrument of corruption. And if you were secure from his corruption, his blessing [ni'mah] would not grieve you. The transmitted reports indicate the prohibition of envy [hasad], and that this dislike is displeasure with the decree of Allah [qada' Allah] in preferring some of His servants over othersâ€”and there is no excuse nor concession for that. What sin [ma'siyah] is greater than your dislike for the comfort of a Muslim when no harm from it reaches you? The Qur'an alludes to this with His saying: "If good befalls you, it grieves them, and if a misfortune strikes you, they rejoice at it." This rejoicing is gloating [shamatah], and envy [hasad] and gloating [shamatah] are inseparable.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
Indeed, how can the mention of proof [hujja] and the demand for it and the investigation into it be forbidden when Allah, the Exalted, has said: "Say, 'Produce your proof [burhanakum]'" (2:111), and the Mighty and Majestic has said: "So that he who perishes might perish by a clear evidence [bayyinah] and he who lives might live by a clear evidence [bayyinah]" (8:42), and He, the Exalted, has said: "Do you have any authority [sultan] for this?" (10:68) meaning any proof [hujja] and evidence [burhan]. And He, the Exalted, has said: "Say, 'Then to Allah belongs the conclusive proof [al-hujjat al-balighah]'" (6:149). And He, the Exalted, has said: "Have you not considered the one who argued with Abraham about his Lord..." (2:258) until His saying: "So the disbeliever was confounded," when He, glorified be He, mentioned Abraham's argumentation [ihtijaj] and his disputation [mujadalah] and his silencing of his opponent in the context of praising him. And the Mighty and Majestic has said: "And that was Our argument [hujjatuna] which We gave Abraham against his people" (6:83). And He, the Exalted, has said: "They said, 'O Noah, you have disputed [jadaltana] with us and been frequent in your dispute [jidalana] with us'" (11:32). And He, the Exalted, has said in the story of Pharaoh: "And what is the Lord of the worlds?" (26:23) until His saying: "If you should come with clear proof [shay'in mubin]" (26:31). And in summary, the Qur'an from its beginning to its end is an argumentation [muhajjah] with the disbelievers. The core of the theologians' proofs in [the matter of] Divine Oneness [tawhid] is His saying, the Exalted: "Had there been within them [the heavens and earth] gods besides Allah, they both would have been ruined" (21:22). And in [the matter of] Prophethood [nubuwwah]: "And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our servant, then produce a surah the like thereof" (2:23). And in [the matter of] the Resurrection [ba'th]: "Say, 'He will give them life who produced them the first time'" (36:79), and other such verses and proofs. And the Messengers, prayers of Allah be upon them, never ceased to argue [yuhajjuna] with the deniers and dispute [yujadilunahum] with them. He, the Exalted, has said: "And argue [jadilhum] with them in a way that is best" (16:125). So the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, also used to argue [yuhajjuna] with the deniers and dispute [yujadiluna] with them, but only when necessary, and the need for it was little in their time. And the first to establish the invitation of the innovators [mubtadi'a] to the truth through disputation [mujadalah] was 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, when he sent Ibn 'Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, to the Khawarij, and he spoke to them. He said, "What do you find fault with regarding your Imam?" They said, "He fought but did not take captives nor take spoils." He said, "That was in fighting the disbelievers. Tell me, if 'A'isha, may Allah be pleased with her, were to be taken as a captive in the share of one of you, would you deem lawful for her what you deem lawful from your spoils, when she is your mother according to the clear text of the Book?" They said, "No." So two thousand of them returned to obedience through his disputation [mujadalatihi]. And it is narrated that Al-Hasan debated [nadhar] a Qadari, so he retracted from [the belief in] Predestination [qadar]. And 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, debated [nadhar] a man from the Qadariyyah. And 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, debated [nadhar] Yazid ibn 'Umayrah concerning faith [iman]. 'Abdullah said, "If I said, 'I am a believer [mu'min],' I would be saying, 'I am in Paradise.'" He said to him...

a.g: Yes [on the contrary], whoever submits his face in Islam to Allah while being a doer of good will have his reward with his Lord. And no fear will there be concerning them, nor will they grieve.

The Jews say "The Christians have nothing [true] to stand on," and the Christians say, "The Jews have nothing to stand on," although they [both] recite the Scripture. Thus the polytheists speak the same as their words. But Allah will judge between them on the Day of Resurrection concerning that over which they used to differ.

And who are more unjust than those who prevent the name of Allah from being mentioned in His mosques and strive toward their destruction. It is not for them to enter them except in fear. For them in this world is disgrace, and they will have in the Hereafter a great punishment.
And to Allah belongs the east and the west. So wherever you [might] turn, there is the Face of Allah. Indeed, Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.
They say, "Allah has taken a son." Exalted is He! Rather, to Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and the earth. All are devoutly obedient to Him,
Originator of the heavens and the earth. When He decrees a matter, He only says to it, "Be," and it is.

Those who do not know say, "Why does Allah not speak to us or there come to us a sign?" Thus spoke those before them like their words. Their hearts resemble each other. We have shown clearly the signs to a people who are certain [in faith].

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
The Seventh Duty: That you do not delve into a discipline [fann] until you have fully mastered the discipline [fann] that precedes it. For the sciences [al-'ulum] are arranged in a necessary order, and some of them are a path to others. The one who is granted success [al-muwaffaq] is he who observes that order and progression. Indeed, Allah the Exalted says: "Those to whom We have given the Book recite it with its true recitation [haqq tilawatihi]" (Al-Baqarah: 121). That is, they do not pass beyond a discipline [fann] until they have perfected it in knowledge ['ilman] and action ['amalan]. And let his intention [qasduhu] in every science ['ilm] he seeks be to ascend to that which is above it.

a.g: O Children of Israel, remember My favor which I have bestowed upon you and that I preferred you over the worlds.
And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all, and no compensation will be accepted from it, nor will any intercession benefit it, nor will they be aided.

And [mention, O Muhammad], when Abraham was tried by his Lord with commands and he fulfilled them. [Allah] said, "Indeed, I will make you a leader for the people." [Abraham] said, "And of my descendants?" [Allah] said, "My covenant does not include the wrongdoers."

And [mention] when We made the House a place of return for the people and [a place of] security. And take, [O believers], from the standing place of Abraham a place of prayer. And We charged Abraham and Ishmael, [saying], "Purify My House for those who perform Tawaf and those who are staying [there] for worship and those who bow and prostrate [in prayer]."

a.g: And who would be averse to the religion of Abraham except one who makes a fool of himself. And We had chosen him in this world, and indeed he, in the Hereafter, will be among the righteous.
When his Lord said to him, "Submit", he said "I have submitted [in Islam] to the Lord of the worlds."
And Abraham instructed his sons [to do the same] and [so did] Jacob, [saying], "O my sons, indeed Allah has chosen for you this religion, so do not die except while you are Muslims."

Or were you witnesses when death approached Jacob, when he said to his sons, "What will you worship after me?" They said, "We will worship your God and the God of your fathers, Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac - one God. And we are Muslims [in submission] to Him."
That was a nation which has passed on. It will have [the consequence of] what it earned, and you will have what you have earned. And you will not be asked about what they used to do.
They say, "Be Jews or Christians [so] you will be guided." Say, "Rather, [we follow] the religion of Abraham, inclining toward truth, and he was not of the polytheists."

Say, [O believers], "We have believed in Allah and what has been revealed to us and what has been revealed to Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants and what was given to Moses and Jesus and what was given to the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and we are Muslims [in submission] to Him."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Prayer
Indeed, some scholars have disliked the recitation of the beginning of some surahs and cutting them short. And it has been narrated that he, peace and blessings be upon him, recited a portion of Surah Yunus, and when he reached the mention of Musa [Moses] and Fir'aun [Pharaoh], he cut it short and bowed. And it has been narrated that he, peace and blessings be upon him, recited in the Fajr [Dawn] prayer a verse from Al-Baqarah, and it is His saying: {Say, 'We have believed in Allah and what has been revealed to us'} [2:136], and in the second [rak'ah]: {Our Lord, we have believed in what You have revealed} [3:53]. And he heard Bilal reciting from here and there, so he asked him about that, and he said: "I mix the good with the good," so he said: "You have done well." And he would recite in the Dhuhr [Noon] prayer with the long surahs of the Mufassal [the concluding portion of the Qur'an] up to thirty verses, and in the 'Asr [Afternoon] prayer with half of that, and in the Maghrib [Sunset] prayer with the last surahs of the Mufassal. And the last prayer the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed was Maghrib, and he recited in it Surah Al-Mursalat; he did not pray after it until he was taken [passed away].

a.g: So if they believe in the same as you believe in, then they have been [rightly] guided; but if they turn away, they are only in dissension, and Allah will be sufficient for you against them. And He is the Hearing, the Knowing.
[And say, "Ours is] the religion of Allah. And who is better than Allah in [ordaining] religion? And we are worshippers of Him."
Say, [O Muhammad], "Do you argue with us about Allah while He is our Lord and your Lord? For us are our deeds, and for you are your deeds. And we are sincere [in deed and intention] to Him."

Or do you say that Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants were Jews or Christians? Say, "Are you more knowing or is Allah?" And who is more unjust than one who conceals a testimony he has from Allah? And Allah is not unaware of what you do.
That is a nation which has passed on. It will have [the consequence of] what it earned, and you will have what you have earned. And you will not be asked about what they used to do.

The foolish among the people will say, "What has turned them away from their qiblah, which they used to face?" Say, "To Allah belongs the east and the west. He guides whom He wills to a straight path."

And thus we have made you a just community that you will be witnesses over the people and the Messenger will be a witness over you. And We did not make the qiblah which you used to face except that We might make evident who would follow the Messenger from who would turn back on his heels. And indeed, it is difficult except for those whom Allah has guided. And never would Allah have caused you to lose your faith. Indeed Allah is, to the people, Kind and Merciful.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
Indeed, I heard Allah, Glorious is His Mention, say: "And We did not make the *qiblah* [qiblah] which you were upon except to distinguish [li-na`lama] who follows the Messenger from him who turns back on his heels. And indeed, it was great except upon those whom Allah has guided. And never would Allah cause your faith [iman] to be lost. Indeed, Allah is, to the people, Kind and Merciful." (2:143) So, regarding those whom Allah has guided from the people of faith [iman], I say: The cousin of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his son-in-law through his daughter, and the most beloved of people to him, and the companion of blessed, preceding merits [sawabiq mubarakat] which were preordained for him by Allahâ€”neither you nor anyone from the people can prevent him from them or come between him and them. And I say: If there is here a pause [hunah] regarding `Ali, then Allah is his Sufficiency [hasbuh]. And by Allah, I do not find concerning him a statement more just than this.

a.g: The truth is from your Lord, so never be among the doubters.

For each [religious following] is a direction toward which it faces. So race to [all that is] good. Wherever you may be, Allah will bring you forth [for judgement] all together. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.
So from wherever you go out [for prayer, O Muhammad] turn your face toward al- Masjid al-Haram, and indeed, it is the truth from your Lord. And Allah is not unaware of what you do.

And from wherever you go out [for prayer], turn your face toward al-Masjid al-Haram. And wherever you [believers] may be, turn your faces toward it in order that the people will not have any argument against you, except for those of them who commit wrong; so fear them not but fear Me. And [it is] so I may complete My favor upon you and that you may be guided.
Just as We have sent among you a messenger from yourselves reciting to you Our verses and purifying you and teaching you the Book and wisdom and teaching you that which you did not know.
So remember Me; I will remember you. And be grateful to Me and do not deny Me.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
Know that God the Exalted has coupled gratitude [shukr] with remembrance [dhikr] in His Book, even though He said: "And the remembrance of God is greater." Indeed, He the Exalted said: "So remember Me; I will remember you. And be grateful to Me and do not deny Me." And He the Exalted said: "What would God do with your punishment if you are grateful and believe?" And He the Exalted said: "And We will reward the grateful." And He, Mighty and Majestic, said, informing about the accursed Iblis: "I will surely sit in wait for them on Your straight path." It is said it is the path of gratitude [shukr], and due to the loftiness of the rank of gratitude [shukr], the accursed one cast aspersions on creation, saying: "And you will not find most of them grateful [shakirin]." And He the Exalted said: "And few of My servants are grateful [shakur]." And God the Exalted has decreed increase with gratitude [shukr] without exception, for He the Exalted said: "If you are grateful, I will surely increase you." And He made exceptions in five things: in granting sufficiency, in answering, in provision, in forgiveness, and in repentance. For He the Exalted said: "Then God will grant you sufficiency from His bounty, if He wills." And He said: "He removes that for which you supplicate Him, if He wills." And He said: "He provides for whom He wills without account." And He said: "And He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills." And He said: "And God turns in forgiveness to whom He wills." And it is a creation from the attributes of Lordship, for He the Exalted said: "And God is Appreciative [shakur] and Forbearing." And God has made gratitude [shukr] the key speech of the people of Paradise, for He the Exalted said: "And they will say, 'Praise to God, who has fulfilled for us His promise.'" And He said: "And their final call will be, 'Praise to God, Lord of the worlds.'" As for the narrations, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "The grateful eater is of the same rank as the patient faster." And it is narrated from 'Ata that he said: "I entered upon 'A'ishah, may God be pleased with her, and said, 'Inform us of the most amazing thing you saw from the Messenger of God, peace be upon him.' She wept and said, 'And which of his affairs was not amazing? He came to me one night and entered the bed with me'â€”or she said, 'my blanket'â€”'until his skin touched my skin. Then he said, "O daughter of Abu Bakr, allow me to worship my Lord." I said, "I love your closeness, but I prefer your desire." So I gave him permission. He stood up to a water-skin, performed ablution without using much water, then stood to pray. He wept until his tears flowed onto his chest. Then he bowed and wept. Then he prostrated and wept. Then he raised his head and wept. He continued like that, weeping, until Bilal came to give the call to prayer. I said, 'O Messenger of God, what makes you weep when God has forgiven your past and future sins?' He said, 'Should I not be a grateful servant [abdan shakura]?'"

a.g: O you who have believed, seek help through patience and prayer. Indeed, Allah is with the patient.
And do not say about those who are killed in the way of Allah, "They are dead." Rather, they are alive, but you perceive [it] not.
And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient,

Vol 2: Etiquette of Earning a Livelihood
Indeed, the third category: that which does not fall under the scope of choice, neither its beginning nor its end, such as calamities [masha'ib]â€”like the death of loved ones, the loss of wealth, the removal of health through illness, the blindness of the eye, the corruption of limbs, and in sum, all other types of affliction [bala']. So patience [sabr] upon that is from the highest stations of patience. Ibn Abbas, may God be pleased with them both, said: "Patience in the Quran is upon three aspects: patience upon performing the obligations [fara'id] of God, the Exalted, for it are three hundred degrees; and patience in abstaining from the prohibitions [maharim] of God, the Exalted, for it are six hundred degrees; and patience upon the calamity [musiba] at the first shock, for it are nine hundred degrees." And this rank is favored, even though it is from the virtues [fada'il] over what preceded itâ€”and they are from the obligationsâ€”because every believer is capable of patience in abstaining from the prohibitions. As for patience upon the affliction [bala'] of God, the Exalted, none can bear it except the Prophets, for it is the merchandise of the truthful [siddiqin]; indeed, that is severe upon the soul [nafs], and for that reason He, peace be upon him, said: "I ask You for such certainty [yaqin] that by it the calamities of the world [dunya] are made light for me." So this is a patience whose foundation is sound certainty [yaqin]. And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "God, Mighty and Majestic, said: 'When I direct a calamity [musiba] to a servant from My servants in his body, or his wealth, or his child, then he meets that with beautiful patience [sabr jamil], I am ashamed before him on the Day of Resurrection to set up a scale for him or to unfurl a record for him.'" And He, peace be upon him, said: "There is no believing servant afflicted by a calamity [musiba] who says as God, the Exalted, has commanded: 'Indeed we belong to God, and indeed to Him we return,' and 'O God, reward me for my calamity and grant me better than it,' except that God will do that for him."

a.g: Indeed, as-Safa and al-Marwah are among the symbols of Allah. So whoever makes Hajj to the House or performs 'umrah - there is no blame upon him for walking between them. And whoever volunteers good - then indeed, Allah is appreciative and Knowing.
Indeed, those who conceal what We sent down of clear proofs and guidance after We made it clear for the people in the Scripture - those are cursed by Allah and cursed by those who curse,
Except for those who repent and correct themselves and make evident [what they concealed]. Those - I will accept their repentance, and I am the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful.
Indeed, those who disbelieve and die while they are disbelievers - upon them will be the curse of Allah and of the angels and the people, all together,
Abiding eternally therein. The punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be reprieved.
And your god is one God. There is no deity [worthy of worship] except Him, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
Indeed, when the heart [qalb] is prepared for the remembrance of God [dhikr Allah] and is stripped of the attachments of the world [dunya], the secret of divine oneness [sirr al-tawhid] is unveiled to it. So when the servant recites at the time of his sleep the saying of God, the Exalted: "And your god is one God. There is no deity except Him..." to His saying: "...for a people who use reason," he remembers that the One God [al-Ilah al-Wahid] is the One deserving of worship to the exclusion of all others. He then deduces from this that the preservation of the Qur'an and the absence of forgetting it are but a blessing from the blessings of this divine oneness [tawhid], for whoever is sincere [akhlasa] to God in his remembrance, God preserves him in his wakefulness and his sleep. Thus, divine oneness [tawhid] necessitates for the servant security [al-amn] and tranquility [al-tuma'ninah], and it protects his heart [qalb] from the distractions [shawaghil] that would make him forget the Book of his Lord.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of the World
Indeed, as for what follows: The world [al-dunya] is an enemy to Allah, and an enemy to the allies [awliya'] of Allah, and an enemy to the enemies of Allah. As for its enmity to Allah: It has cut off the path [al-tariq] from the servants of Allah. And for that reason, Allah has not looked upon it since He created it. And as for its enmity to the allies [awliya'] of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic: It adorned itself for them with its adornment, and blinded them with its splendor and freshness, until they drank the bitterness of patience [al-sabr] in severing ties with it. And as for its enmity to the enemies of Allah: It gradually lured them with its guile and its plot, then snatched them with its net, until they placed their trust in it and relied upon it. Then it abandoned them at the time of their greatest need for it. So they reaped from it a regret [hasra] that causes hearts [al-akbad] to be torn apart. Then it deprived them of felicity [al-sa'ada] for all eternity. They are in separation from it, regretful, and from its plots they cry for help, but they are not given succor. Rather, it is said to them: "Be driven into it, and do not speak to Me. Those are the ones who purchased the worldly life [al-hayat al-dunya] with the Hereafter [al-akhira]; so the punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be helped."

a.g: Those are the ones who have exchanged guidance for error and forgiveness for punishment. How patient they are in pursuit of the Fire!
That is [deserved by them] because Allah has sent down the Book in truth. And indeed, those who differ over the Book are in extreme dissension.

Righteousness is not that you turn your faces toward the east or the west, but [true] righteousness is [in] one who believes in Allah, the Last Day, the angels, the Book, and the prophets and gives wealth, in spite of love for it, to relatives, orphans, the needy, the traveler, those who ask [for help], and for freeing slaves; [and who] establishes prayer and gives zakah; [those who] fulfill their promise when they promise; and [those who] are patient in poverty and hardship and during battle. Those are the ones who have been true, and it is those who are the righteous.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
Know that patience [sabr] is of two kinds. The first is a bodily kind, such as enduring hardships with the body and remaining steadfast upon them. This is either through action, such as undertaking strenuous works, whether from acts of worship or otherwise, or through endurance, such as patience [sabr] with severe beating, great illness, and terrible wounds. This can be praiseworthy if it conforms to the Sacred Law, but the complete praiseworthy kind is the other kind, which is the patience [sabr] of the soul [nafs] from the desires of one's nature and the demands of caprice [hawa]. Then, this kind, if it is patience [sabr] against the desire of the stomach and the private parts, it is called chastity ['iffa]. If it is in enduring a disliked thing, its names differ among people according to the difference of the disliked thing which patience [sabr] has overcome. If it is in a calamity, it is confined to the name 'patience' [sabr], and its opposite state is called panic [jaza'] and alarm [hala'], which is releasing the caller of caprice [hawa] to give free rein in raising the voice, striking the cheeks, tearing the collars, and other such acts. If it is in enduring wealth, it is called self-restraint [dabt al-nafs], and its opposite state is called arrogance [batr]. If it is in war and fighting, it is called courage [shaja'a], and its opposite is cowardice [jubn]. If it is in suppressing rage and anger, it is called forbearance [hilm], and its opposite is complaint [tadammur]. If it is in an afflicting calamity from the calamities of time, it is called breadth of the chest [sa'at al-sadr], and its opposite is impatience [dajar] and vexation [tabarram] and narrowness of the chest [dayq al-sadr]. If it is in concealing speech, it is called keeping a secret [kitman al-sirr], and its possessor is called secretive [katum]. If it is from the excesses of life, it is called renunciation [zuhd], and its opposite is greed [hirs]. If it is patience [sabr] upon a small portion of shares, it is called contentment [qana'a], and its opposite is avarice [sharah]. Thus, most of the character traits of faith [iman] are included within patience [sabr]. For this reason, when He, peace be upon him, was once asked about faith [iman], he said: "It is patience [sabr]," because its acts are many and most noble, just as He said: "Perform Hajj at 'Arafah." And Allah, the Exalted, has gathered all these divisions and named the whole of it 'patience' [sabr], saying, the Exalted: "And those who are patient [al-sabirin] in poverty [al-ba'sa']" â€“ meaning calamity â€“ "and hardship [al-darra']" â€“ meaning poverty â€“ "and when in battle [hina al-ba's]" â€“ meaning warfare â€“ "It is they who have been true, and it is they who are the righteous [al-muttaqun]." Therefore, these are the divisions of patience [sabr] according to the differences of their objects.

a.g: O you who have believed, prescribed for you is legal retribution for those murdered - the free for the free, the slave for the slave, and the female for the female. But whoever overlooks from his brother anything, then there should be a suitable follow-up and payment to him with good conduct. This is an alleviation from your Lord and a mercy. But whoever transgresses after that will have a painful punishment.
And there is for you in legal retribution [saving of] life, O you [people] of understanding, that you may become righteous.

Prescribed for you when death approaches [any] one of you if he leaves wealth [is that he should make] a bequest for the parents and near relatives according to what is acceptable - a duty upon the righteous.
Then whoever alters the bequest after he has heard it - the sin is only upon those who have altered it. Indeed, Allah is Hearing and Knowing.
But if one fears from the bequeather [some] error or sin and corrects that which is between them, there is no sin upon him. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
O you who have believed, decreed upon you is fasting as it was decreed upon those before you that you may become righteous -

[Fasting for] a limited number of days. So whoever among you is ill or on a journey [during them] - then an equal number of days [are to be made up]. And upon those who are able [to fast, but with hardship] - a ransom [as substitute] of feeding a poor person [each day]. And whoever volunteers excess - it is better for him. But to fast is best for you, if you only knew.

The month of Ramadhan [is that] in which was revealed the Qur'an, a guidance for the people and clear proofs of guidance and criterion. So whoever sights [the new moon of] the month, let him fast it; and whoever is ill or on a journey - then an equal number of other days. Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship and [wants] for you to complete the period and to glorify Allah for that [to] which He has guided you; and perhaps you will be grateful.

a.g: It has been made permissible for you the night preceding fasting to go to your wives [for sexual relations]. They are clothing for you and you are clothing for them. Allah knows that you used to deceive yourselves, so He accepted your repentance and forgave you. So now, have relations with them and seek that which Allah has decreed for you. And eat and drink until the white thread of dawn becomes distinct to you from the black thread [of night]. Then complete the fast until the sunset. And do not have relations with them as long as you are staying for worship in the mosques. These are the limits [set by] Allah, so do not approach them. Thus does Allah make clear His ordinances to the people that they may become righteous.

And do not consume one another's wealth unjustly or send it [in bribery] to the rulers in order that [they might aid] you [to] consume a portion of the wealth of the people in sin, while you know [it is unlawful].

Vol 2: The Lawful and Prohibited
Indeed, the Most High has said: "And do not consume your wealth [amwalakum] among yourselves unjustly [bil-batil]." And the Most High has said: "Indeed, those who consume the wealth of orphans unjustly..." And the Most High has said: "O you who have believed, fear Allah [ittaqullah] and give up what remains [of interest] if you should be believers." Then He said: "But if you do not, then be informed of a war [harb] from Allah and His Messenger." Then He said: "And if you repent, then for you are your principal sums." Then He said: "And whoever returns [to dealing in interest] â€“ those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally." He made the consumer of interest [akil al-riba], at the beginning of the matter, one who announces war [mu'dhin bi harb], and at its end, one who exposes himself to the Fire [mut'arrid lil-nar]. And the verses revealed concerning the lawful [al-halal] and the unlawful [al-haram] are beyond count.

a.g: They ask you, [O Muhammad], about the new moons. Say, "They are measurements of time for the people and for Hajj." And it is not righteousness to enter houses from the back, but righteousness is [in] one who fears Allah. And enter houses from their doors. And fear Allah that you may succeed.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Companionship
Indeed, We have mentioned this in the Book of the Etiquettes of Companionship. And likewise, what has been narrated: that 'Umar, may God be pleased with him, climbed over the wall of a man's house and saw him in a reprehensible state, so he reproached him. The man said, "O Commander of the Faithful, if I have disobeyed God in one respect, you have disobeyed Him in three." He said, "And what are they?" He said, "Indeed, God the Exalted has said, 'And do not spy [wa la tajassasu],' and you have spied. And He the Exalted has said, 'And enter houses from their doors [wa'tu al-buyuta min abwabiha],' and you have scaled the roof. a.g: Fight in the way of Allah those who fight you but do not transgress. Indeed. Allah does not like transgressors.

Fight them until there is no [more] fitnah and [until] worship is [acknowledged to be] for Allah. But if they cease, then there is to be no aggression except against the oppressors.

a.g: And complete the Hajj and 'umrah for Allah. But if you are prevented, then [offer] what can be obtained with ease of sacrificial animals. And do not shave your heads until the sacrificial animal has reached its place of slaughter. And whoever among you is ill or has an ailment of the head [making shaving necessary must offer] a ransom of fasting [three days] or charity or sacrifice. And when you are secure, then whoever performs 'umrah [during the Hajj months] followed by Hajj [offers] what can be obtained with ease of sacrificial animals. And whoever cannot find [or afford such an animal] - then a fast of three days during Hajj and of seven when you have returned [home]. Those are ten complete [days]. Perhaps you say: "These reports indicate that tribulation [bala'] is better in this world [dunya] than blessings [ni'am]. So, is it for us to ask Allah for tribulation?" I say: There is no basis for that, because it is narrated from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he would seek refuge in his supplication from the tribulation of this world and the tribulation of the Hereafter [akhira]. And he, and the Prophets, peace be upon them, would say: "Our Lord, grant us good in this world and good in the Hereafter." And they would seek refuge from the gloating of enemies and other things. And 'Ali, may Allah honor his face, said: "O Allah, I ask You for patience [sabr]." So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "You have asked for tribulation, so ask Him for well-being ['afiya]." And it is narrated from al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "Ask Allah for well-being, for no one has been given anything better than well-being except certainty [yaqin]." And he indicated by 'certainty' the well-being of the heart [qalb] from the sickness of ignorance [jahl] and doubt [shakk]. So the well-being of the heart is higher than the well-being of the body. And al-Hasan, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The good in which there is no evil is well-being with gratitude [shukr], for how many are those upon whom blessings are bestowed who are not grateful." And Mutarrif ibn 'Abdullah said: "That I be granted well-being and be grateful is more beloved to me than that I be afflicted and be patient." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said in his supplication: "And Your well-being is more beloved to me." This is clearer than to need proof and evidence for it. And this is because tribulation becomes a blessing [ni'ma] by two considerations: One of them is in relation to what is greater than it, either in this world or in religion [din]. And the other is in relation to what is hoped for of reward [thawab]. Therefore, we should ask Allah for the perfection of blessing in this world and the removal of what is beyond it of tribulation. And we ask Him for reward in the Hereafter for gratitude [shukr] for His blessing, for He is capable of granting for gratitude what He does not grant for patience.

Then he recited: "Indeed, Allah loves those who constantly repent [al-tawwabin]." Vol 2: Etiquette of Sama and Wajd
Indeed, Allah does not hold you accountable for your oaths which are unintentional [al-laghw], but He holds you accountable for what your hearts [qalb] have earned. And the truth [al-haqq] in this matter, in our view, cannot be grasped without encompassing the detailed workings of the hearts [qalb] from the initial point of their appearance until the action manifests upon the limbs. So We say: The first thing that occurs to the heart [qalb] is the passing thought [al-khatir], as if, for example, the image of a woman occurs to it, and that she is behind him on the roadâ€”if he were to turn to her, he would see her. The second is the stirring of desire to look, which is the movement of appetite [al-shahwa] in the natural disposition [al-tab']. This is generated from the first thought [al-khatir], and We call it the inclination of the natural disposition [al-tab']. The first is called the whisper of the soul [hadith al-nafs]. The third is the judgment [hukm] of the heart [qalb] that this ought to be doneâ€”meaning, he ought to look at her. For when the natural disposition [al-tab'] inclines, resolve [al-himma] and intention [al-niyya] are not set in motion unless the deterrents are removed. For he may be prevented by shame [al-haya'] or fear from turning. The absence of these deterrents may be due to reflection [al-ta'ammul], and this, in any case, is a judgment from the side of the intellect [al-'aql]. This is called a belief [i'tiqad], and it follows the thought [al-khatir] and the inclination [al-mayl]. The fourth is the firm resolve [tasmeem al-'azm] to turn and the decisive intention [jazm al-niyya] therein. This We call an actual concern [hamm bi al-fi'l] and an intention [niyya] and an aim [qasd]. This concern [al-hamm] may have a weak beginning, but if the heart [qalb] heeds the first thought [al-khatir] until its attraction for the soul [al-nafs] is prolonged, this concern [al-hamm] becomes confirmed and becomes a decisive will [irada majzuma]. So when the will [al-irada] is decisively formed, perhaps he regrets after the resolve [al-jazm] and abandons the action, or perhaps he is distracted by an incidental matter and does not act upon it and does not turn to it, or perhaps an obstacle hinders him so the action becomes impossible for him. Here, then, are four states [ahwal] of the heart [qalb] before action by the limb: the thought [al-khatir], which is the whisper of the soul [hadith al-nafs]; then the inclination [al-mayl]; then the belief [al-i'tiqad]; then the concern [al-hamm]. So We say: As for the thought [al-khatir], one is not held accountable for it because it does not fall under choice [al-ikhtiyar]. Likewise, the inclination [al-mayl] and the stirring of appetite [al-shahwa], because they also do not fall under choice [al-ikhtiyar]. These two are what is intended by His saying, peace be upon him: "My community is forgiven for what their souls [nufus] whisper to them." For "the whisper of the soul [hadith al-nafs]" is an expression for the thoughts [al-khawatir] that whisper in the soul [al-nafs] and are not followed by a resolve [al-'azm] to act. As for the concern [al-hamm] and the resolve [al-'azm], they are not called the whisper of the soul [hadith al-nafs]. Rather, the whisper of the soul [hadith al-nafs] is as was narrated from 'Uthman ibn Maz'un when he said to the Prophet, peace be upon him: "O Messenger of Allah, my soul [nafs] whispers to me that I should divorce Khawla." He said: "Gently. Marriage is from my way [sunnati]." He said: "My soul [nafs] whispers to me that I should deny myself." He said: "Gently."

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
Indeed, Bishr ibn al-Harith said: "Ahmad ibn Hanbal was superior to me in three matters: in seeking the lawful [halal] for himself and for others, while I seek it only for myself; in his expansiveness in marriage [nikah] and my restriction from it; and because he established himself as an imam for the common people." And it is said that Ahmad, may God have mercy on him, married on the second day after the death of the mother of his son, Abdullah, and said: "I dislike to spend the night unmarried." As for Bishr, when it was said to him: "The people speak about you for your abandonment of marriage, and they say he is one who abandons the Sunnah," he said: "Say to them: He is occupied with the obligatory [fard] over the Sunnah." And he was reproached another time, so he said: "Nothing prevents me from marriage except His saying, the Most High: 'And for them [women] is the like of what is upon them in kindness [ma'ruf].'" This was mentioned to Ahmad, so he said: "And where is the like of Bishr? Indeed, he has sat upon the like of the spear's edge." He said: "He raised my stations in Paradise, and elevated me to behold the stations of the Prophets, yet I did not reach the stations of the married ones." And in another narration, He said to me: "I did not love that you meet Me unmarried."

Indeed, if you say: "Why did 'Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, abandon marriage despite its virtue, and if the superior path is to be free for the worship of Allah, then why did our Messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, take many wives?" And our Messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, took the path of strength and combined the virtue of worship ['ibada] and marriage. And now let us mention the virtue of pardon [al-'afw] and beneficence [al-ihsan]. The virtue of pardon [al-'afw] and beneficence [al-ihsan]â€”know that the meaning of pardon [al-'afw] is that a right is due, and one relinquishes it and absolves from it, whether from retaliation or a fine, and it is other than forbearance [al-hilm] and suppressing anger [kazm al-ghayz]; therefore, we have singled it out. Allah, the Exalted, says: "And that you pardon [ta'fu] is nearer to piety [al-taqwa]." And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Three thingsâ€”by the One in Whose hand is my soul, if I were one to swear an oath, I would swear upon them: No wealth is diminished by charity, so give charity. And no man pardons [afa] an injustice [mazlima] seeking by it the Face of Allah except that Allah increases him in honor ['izz] by it on the Day of Resurrection. And no man opens for himself the door of begging [mas'ala] except that Allah opens for him the door of poverty [faqr]." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Humility [al-tawadu'] does not increase the servant except in elevation [rif'a], so be humble and Allah will elevate you. And pardon [al-'afw] does not increase the servant except in honor ['izz], so pardon and Allah will honor you. And charity [al-sadaqa] does not increase wealth except in abundance, so give charity and Allah will have mercy upon you." And 'Uqbah said: "I met the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, one day, and I hastened to him and took his hand, or he hastened to me and took my hand, and he said: 'O 'Uqbah, shall I not inform you of the best character traits of the people of this world [ahl al-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhira]: You maintain ties with one who severs you, you give to one who deprives you, and you pardon [ta'fu] one who wrongs you.'" And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Musa, upon him be peace, said: 'O Lord, which of Your servants is most honorable ['azza] to You?' He said: 'The one who, when he has power, pardons [y'afu].'" Likewise, Abu al-Darda' was asked about the most honorable of people, and he said: "The one who pardons [ya'fu] when he has power." So pardon, and Allah will honor you.

And it indicates that this is not from the condition of reliance [tawakkul] what was narrated from 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, and from the Companions concerning the story of the plague. For when they intended to go to Syria and reached al-Jabiyah, the news reached them that there was in it a great death and a swift pestilence. So the people split into two groups. Some of them said: "We will not enter upon the pestilence, thus casting ourselves by our hands into destruction." And another group said: "Rather, we will enter and rely [natawakkul], and we will not flee from the decree [qadar] of Allah, the Exalted, nor flee from death, lest we be like those concerning whom Allah, the Exalted, said: 'Have you not seen those who left their homes while they were thousands, fearing death?'" So they returned to 'Umar and asked him about his opinion. He said: "We return and do not enter upon the pestilence." Those who disagreed with his opinion said to him: "Do you flee from the decree [qadar] of Allah, the Exalted?" 'Umar said: "Yes, we flee from the decree [qadar] of Allah to the decree [qadar] of Allah." Then he struck for them an example, saying: "What is your view if one of you had sheep and they descended into a valley that had two branchesâ€”one of them fertile and the other barrenâ€”is it not that if he grazes the fertile one, he grazes it by the decree [qadar] of Allah, the Exalted, and if he grazes the barren one, he grazes it by the decree [qadar] of Allah, the Exalted?" They said: "Yes." Then he sought 'Abd al-Rahman ibn 'Awf to ask him about his opinionâ€”and he was absent. When morning came, 'Abd al-Rahman came and 'Umar asked him about that. He said: "I have concerning it, O Commander of the Believers, something I heard from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him." 'Umar said: "Allah is the Greatest." 'Abd al-Rahman said: "I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: 'If you hear of a pestilence in a land, do not proceed towards it, and if it occurs in a land and you are in it, do not depart from it fleeing from it.'" So 'Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, rejoiced at that and praised Allah, the Exalted, since it agreed with his opinion, and he returned from al-Jabiyah with the people.
